intro: Thryptomene helmsii, commonly known as the narrow-leaf thryptomene, is a small shrub native to the coastal regions of southern Australia. It belongs to the Myrtaceae family, which includes eucalyptus and tea trees, and is characterized by its aromatic leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in sandy or rocky soils and is adapted to coastal conditions, including salt spray and strong winds. Its leaves are narrow and lance-shaped, with a leathery texture, and it produces white or pale pink flowers during the spring and summer months. Thryptomene helmsii is often found in heathlands and is an important component of the local flora in its native habitat.
